awd_abstract_narration:
Manifolds are spaces locally resemble Euclidean spaces, and are the main object of research in Geometry, with applications to all areas of mathematics and theoretical physics. The principal investigator's project is centered on one of the most classical problems in Geometry:  determining which metric is the best for a given manifold. A metric is a mathematical way of measuring the distance and angles in a manifold. The project's research will require the use of different techniques from several areas of mathematics: differential, algebraic and symplectic geometry, analysis, dynamical systems, and topology. The PI will take advantage of working at The City College of New York to reach underrepresented groups in the sciences, as this institution has an unusually high percentage of minority students.

Dr. Santoro's plan of research breaks down into three main projects revolving around various notions of "special metrics" in differential geometry. The special metrics appearing in the first project, about aspects of the classification of ALE scalar-flat surfaces, can be seen as a generalization to gravitational instantons. The PI's second project is the study of a collapsed Dirichlet problem (at infinity) of complete constant mean curvature hypersurfaces in hyperbolic space. Yet another notion of special metrics are the Hermitian-Einstein metrics, a generalization of Kahler-Einstein metrics for vector bundles: in the third project, the PI proposes the development of new notions of stability in Yang-Mills theory for non-holomorphic vector bundles.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant supported the PI?s research in the field of Geometric Analysis, which concerns the study of high-dimensional objects (called manifolds) that model our universe. More specifically, the understanding of how those objects are curved provides insight on the structure of the whole space. Analysis and Partial Differential equations are the usual techniques used to study the curvature of manifolds. 

One of the directions of research carried out during this award stems from the geometry of Calabi-Yau manifolds. In broad words, physicists believe that our universe is ten-dimensional: in addition to the usual four dimensions (three spacial directions plus time), there exist 6 microscopic dimensions, which form the so-called ?Calabi-Yau spaces?. In our usual everyday life, it is not possible to perceive this extra 6 dimensions, but they are fundamental to the complete understanding of the universe. The understanding of Calabi-Yau spaces sparked many further questions, in particular the direction of research on the so-called Asymptotically Locally Euclidean Kaehler surfaces, funded by this PI?s award. 
While the research funded by this grant allowed for international collaborations, seminars and training of graduate students, the main impact to the general public is through teaching. While the research carried out by the PI is certainly more advanced than the topics covered in the courses offered to undergraduates and masters students at the City College of New York, it forced the PI to constantly rethink and improve the exposition of foundational material to students. Working at a minority-serving institution placed the PI in a unique position to magnify this impact. This hopefully contributed, even if ever-so-slightly, to the decrease of the great disparity in minority education in STEM fields.
